 It's a sad commentary on history education that people don't know how the US Constitution came about.
 
 In fact the US was a confederation of independent nations (hint: that's why they called them "states" and not "provinces").
 
 The first attempt at building a truly central US government, the Articles of Confederation, failed. They did so in large part because the states didn't much like the idea of a central government telling them what to do. The Revolutionary War had been won largely based on local troops and after it was over, the standing army was all but disbanded. 
 
 That is why the preamble to our current Constitution reads "We the People, in order to form a more perfect union..." it was because the first attempt had been such a joke.
 
 Keep in mind that the states had their own currencies, customs and so forth - just like the Europeans.
